author: -Eb4i-
body:
Tax brackets don’t work like that. For simplicity: Lets say the brackets are 
0% @ <$10k
10% @ $10k
20% @ $50k
30% @ $100k
35% @ $250k

you made $300k
First $10k you pay no taxes on
$40k is taxed at 10%
$50k is taxed at 20%
$150k is taxed at 30%
$50k is taxed at 35%

So not including state in this example your fed taxes would be $76.5k or around 25.5% on average.

No need to try and get into a lower bracket. It’s only the additional money you make beyond each threshold that is taxed at the new brackets rate. 

The reason some people pay close to 50% (and sometimes more) is because they are way beyond the final bracket threshold, so their average is higher. Toss in a tax rate of around 10% for state and it starts to look a lot more like 50%

author: BetterThanBuffet
body:
Don't have any. Most people *should* just buy indexes. The people who give that advice *are* actually more knowledgeable than the people who should follow that advice but don't. The problem is that it's just not worth the effort to convince that middle tier of people I'm more knowledgeable than them. In part because *everybody* thinks they're more knowledgeable than that.

If your strategy works, ignore them. If it doesn't, consider listening to them. And realize that for most people, that advice is actually quite accurate, and you may be doing more harm to bystanders than good by contradicting them. If it's a pride thing that's bothering you, that's what you need to work on. Pride has no place in investing.

Buyer has all the real information over the seller.

author: slippygibby
body:
\>"The price of the stock shouldn’t even matter. You own a part of a great company."

That isn't really true, though. If you bought Microsoft at any point in 1999, it would have taken 15 years for the price to break even after the 2000 crash. The price you're paying matters, and it's silly to act like it doesn't. 

Maybe it's enough of a challenge that for the average investor it's reasonable to triage and just buy a good company at any price. But a good buy is always, always, always a function of both 

1) how good a company is fundamentally

2) how high a price you're paying.

Ignoring price is ignoring half of investing. On average it'll work out okay for all the same reasons it works out OK to just auto-pilot DCA into an S&P 500 fund all the time, without worrying about if the market is overpriced. But it's disingenuous to act like price is unimportant.

author: Nosefuroughtto
body:
I find it odd to consider Amazon like Standard Oil. SO derived it’s monopolistic power through acquisitions of rival refineries and distributors; purely horizontal integration, followed by outright price fixing.

Amazon is absolutely massive, but the growth method and diversity of markets they participate in distinguishes them from old trust oriented monopolies. I’m terms of AWS, the majority of growth was organic, and would not have ran afoul of antitrust law back in its hay day, such as when US v. Aluminum Co. of America was prevailing law.

An attempt to break up Amazon by business segment would probably fail due to the shift since the 70’s from Per Se Antitrust violations to the Rule of Reason. They aren’t dominating any given sector to the point that a court could likely prove anti-consumer behavior, which has increasingly become the prime factor.

Online shopping has a fairly rich market with Walmart, Home Depot, Best Buy, wayfair, etc.; physical stores obviously have Walmart and target being dominant; subscription services are still beaten by Netflix and Google, with Disney catching up fast; AWS competes with Oracle, Microsoft snd Google.

Overall I think the justifications for breaking up Amazon are weak in light of the method of growth, the fact that they aren’t shutting out competitors in any given industry right now, and our much more consumer viewpoint focus on antitrust enforcement.

author: FlameoHotman-_-
body:
This has to be an unpopular opinion...and for the record, I distrust the CCP as much as the next person, but these crackdowns may not be entirely bad. Let's look at some examples:

\- So in this case, Didi's operation got suspended because "Didi had illegally collected users' personal data."

\- Alibaba got fined because of monopolistic practices.

\- Ant Group's IPO got slashed because the CCP wanted to regulate Ant Group like an actual bank.

To be honest, these sound pretty reasonable to me. Facebook was in trouble for collecting data without content too. Remember the whole Cambridge Analytica scandal? But now everyone is hot for FB stocks.

Microsoft has been fined millions by the EU for monopolistic practices as well. But everyone loves Microsoft stocks nonetheless. 

And as to Ant Group, they are a massive financial service company that can offer customers credit. How come they don't get to be regulated like a bank? My point is that these actions make sense and good regulations is beneficial for investors too in the long run.

author: Pdicky69
body:
$NET is on a fundamental basis is over valued. They expect rev to be $500M+ this year but they trade at $33B. It’s been on of my biggest picked winners. 

Here is a quick breakdown of what the popular services they offer, highly scaleable and a HUGE TAM.

https://www.freelancer.com/articles/web-development/cloudflare

However I sold off at $75, $85 levels due to price action getting ahead of the fundamental business. I’ve exited about 50% of my position. I still have 200 shares because I believe, it could do some long term stuff well and be a $100B company. But I can’t allocate so much of my portfolio in this company vs a FB/AMZN/GOOG (where I get growth, balance sheet safety, and moat)

From here, if you want to get in on the action. You have to believe they do a few things…
1) surprise HEAVILY on revenue growth and forward guidance
2) grow more into their cyber security suite of tools beyond just basic stuff like their widely used DDOS prevention (a ton of websites use them for this) and firewall 
3) Content delivery network investment trend continues and profit margins aren’t competed away with bigger boys entering the game (ie GOOG, MSFT, AMZN)
4) website speeds overwhelmingly determine ranking on google and mobile searches

Cloudflare and Fastly are the two more popular services for websites and apps to use as they offer ease of use to speed up website access for users and support to prevent website downtime. Folks have frequently complimented on how easy cloudflare is to use.

author: __SlimeQ__
body:
I've been watching this for a while and I think $10 is the bottom. CP2077 was a very big oopsie and the company will probably be living it down for a long time. There is positive news coming out sometimes but also there's pretty consistent bad news about CP2077. The runup last year was obviously just because of CP2077 hype and really had no legs to stand on.

That being said, they **own GoG** which is the only DRM free marketplace I am aware of. I personally really like buying games there because unlike steam, I can buy one copy and play with my girlfriend on a separate computer. This is a pretty strong niche that I don't think will be going anywhere. Microsoft allows you to technically play on 2 machines if you game the system, but their PC marketplace is currently very sparse. Unless the PC Microsoft store massively expands their indie game library I can really only imagine GoG getting bigger and better over time. **BUT,** if Microsoft does manage to attract smaller indie devs this use case will become less important.

Microsoft in the 1990s was the most valuable company in the world switching spots with GE, it is currently the only company that was in the top 10 list in 1990 and is currently still top 10 right now (at #2 spot behind apple). It was the #1 company by marketcap in 2019 and march 2020.

Microsoft continues to invest in the future with the cloud technology, ai, vr/ar tech as well as is extremely diversified with equal 33% weight in 3 different classified segments.(the other trillion companies aren't as diversified). It faces less regulatory risk than tech giants competitors allowing for easy acquisitions thanks to its stellar balance sheet.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_public_corporations_by_market_capitalization#2012

author: harrison_wintergreen
body:
ELI5: 

- Burry believes (as he wrote): "passive investing has removed price discovery from the equity markets". https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-04/michael-burry-explains-why-index-funds-are-like-subprime-cdos

- price discovery is the process of estimating a reasonable fair value for a stock. 

- because relatively few people are buying/selling stocks based on their fair value, prices for stocks are often being determined mainly by cash-flows. see Tesla or dogecoin for examples. Tesla sells under 1% all vehicles worldwide but is somehow worth *more than all the other carmakers combined* because lots of people were buying Tesla stock and not because of any financial status of Tesla. dogecoin started LITERALLY as a joke but somehow was more valuable than companies like Ford Motors only because a ton of cash flowed into Dogecoin. this is all sheer insanity by traditional stock valuation guidelines. asset bubbles are nothing new, but Burry believes it's being exacerbated by passive investing. 

- Burry believes this situation of prices being based on cash flows is similar to what happened in the housing bubble, when multi-zillion Collateralized Debt Obligations (CDOs) were being priced not by a reasonable estimate of their fair value but by cash-flows. 

- when flows reverse and lots of people want out of index funds, it will get ugly because so many stocks are linked/benchmarked to major stock indexes *including lower volume stocks*. consider VTI: the top holdings (Apple, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson) might have a billion shares in total and hundreds of millions of dollars trading each day. but the smallest company stocks might have only a few million shares and a few million dollars trading each day. if too many people want to sell all at the same time, it will drive prices down sharply because these stocks are so often sold as a bundle/unit. as Burry puts it: "The theater keeps getting more crowded, but the exit door is the same as it always was"

>since the guy predicted 2007-2008 crash.

he also predicted the dot-com bubble.

author: zxc123zxc123
body:
Hi. I'm from the Intel side! I think AMD side shouldn't worry too much about INTC. It's a big old ship that's getting bombarded from all sides. The fact that it's a big ship means it's changes will take time. I'm giving Gelsinger a chance to right the ship, but it will take a long while to undo BSwan's bad moves, get the right people, develop the chips, and catch up to AMD. 

A plus side for everyone is that the semi-space is a growing area with electronification, digitization, and "5G-cloudification" of everything along with the increasing importance of AI & tech in business and government. Semis are so important in fact, that at this point US Gov should really be looking at INTC/NVD/TI more like they did Ford/GM 100 years ago: as a strategic industrial/military resource. 

Real threat to AMD isn't INTC. INTC was the big market share holder in the past and isn't likely gaining any ground any time soon. What AMD and all the trad chip manufacturers should fear is FAAAM & BAT. Apple has started designing it's own chips. They aren't going back to using outsourced chips. If history says anything it's that Apple will continue to cut others out as they continue to in-house their chips for their entire lineup while improving their chips just like how they kept improving their computers, just like how the iphone kept improving until NOK/MOT were beat, just like how a good chunk of the watch market is Apple watches, just like how Ipads have taken away from of the laptop space, just like how Apple TV keeps chipping away at cable, just like how the app store and Apple's eco system keeps growing, etcetcetc. There is nothing AMD/NVD/INTC can do to stop Apple. And Apple is just the first. MSFT also doing the same. Google, Facebook, and Amazon might follow suit. China's Tencent and Alibaba will likely copy what the US companies do as soon as Pooh Bear gets done man handling them.

Mentioned:	AMC GME MSFT SONY
By Connor Smith 

Long before retail investors on Reddit flooded online forums theorizing about GameStop, investor Michael Burry spotted an out-of-favor stock that was misunderstood. Now, Burry says he sees shades of 1999 and 2007 -- periods of other market frothiness. 

"I don't know when meme stocks such as this will crash, but we probably do not have to wait too long, as I believe the retail crowd is fully invested in this theme, and Wall Street has jumped on the coattails," Burry told Barron's via email. "We're running out of new money available to jump on the bandwagon." 

Burry, whose successful bet against the housing market ahead of the subprime mortgage collapse made him a prominent character in the book and movie "The Big Short," believes that meme stocks are the latest Wall Street trend that could wind up hurting regular investors. He said that in 1999, everyone making money in dot-com stocks believed it would continue. In 2007, those making money "leveraged to the hilt in multiple homes" thought that would continue, too. 

"Momentum, social media are now part of the strategy for Wall Street, and they are in a better position than retail to participate, sniff out and start gamma squeezes in the options market," Burry added, the latter part referring to heightened demand for shares driven by market makers rushing to hedge call options they sold -- a phenomenon that likely juiced meme stock trading. 

Burry became a high-profile GameStop (ticker: GME) bull in the second half of 2019. He told Barron's in August of that year that fears about disc-less consoles were overblown. He expected free cash flow to rebound when new consoles from Sony and Microsoft were released in 2020. On the now-viral RoaringKitty YouTube channel that predicted the GameStop squeeze potential, retail investor Keith Gill touted Burry's bull thesis. Burry couldn't have foreseen the pandemic and related console shortages, but his thesis was certainly playing out, as shares began to rebound in the second half of 2020. 

"For me though, if I get within years on a thesis coming true, I'm happy, " he says. "Most people are focused on days, weeks or months." 

In 2020, after Chewy co-founder Ryan Cohen revealed a 9% stake in the company and called for major changes, shares rallied back to double-digit territory. Burry sold what was left of his GameStop stake at a profit at some point during the fourth quarter of last year, according to regulatory filings. 

Asked about companies like GameStop and AMC Entertainment Holdings (AMC) that have sold millions of shares into surging stock prices, Burry points out that is wasn't that long ago that GameStop was buying back millions of dollars in stock at his suggestion. 

He thinks companies should be selling stock -- as long as they follow the laws. 

"This is a Godsend for these companies," Burry added. "But just having cash on hand itself does not warrant high multiples from the market, as many, many listed companies can tell you." 

Write to Connor Smith at connor.smith@barrons.com 

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

author: Dolos2279
body:
I mostly invest in index funds largely for the reasons you gave lol and I do think markets are fairly efficient overall. I also just don't like spending significant time doing research into single stocks. It's just not that fun to me. However, I do have a sizeable amount of my portfolio in Microsoft, which is my only single stock investment. With that said, some people do okay with stock picking and some just have fun with it, so there isn't anything wrong with it IMO. 


Here are couple things you could say (not really one liners, but you could easily paraphrase):

1.) It's fun and you enjoy doing research into stocks. As long as you're managing your risk, you'll still probably make money and will have fun doing it even if you underperform or just have the same performance as the market. There's also the possibility you could outperform and make more by doing proper research. 

2.) Even if you believe in efficient markets, that doesn't mean beating the market is impossible. It just means you likely have to take on more risk to do it. It might work, it might not. Higher risk is rewarded with higher returns, so if you're okay with the added risk, there's the possibility of making more money (ideally with at least some divetsification).

3.) People often misunderstand the role of entities like hedge funds and other pro money managers. I worked at a large hedge fund (not as a trader) and we rarely beat the S&P 500 in a given year in total return lol. Clients for hedge funds often are wealthy individuals or others such as pension funds who simply want a reasonable return that isn't 100% correlated with the market, so if the S&P tanks they don't lose everything. Some do take on a ton of risk, but they usually blow up within a few years. The ones that stay around generally have higher Sharpe ratios than the broader market, but in total returns they often lag, yet they still have clients because the goal isn't always to just beat the market. Their strategies can also sometimes be constrained by a large AUM. With less capital, you can actually take on different strategies than the pros are able to and it's entirely possible for these strategies to do well.

author: FlameoHotman-_-
body:
This has to be an unpopular opinion...and for the record, I distrust the CCP as much as the next person, but these crackdowns may not be entirely bad. Let's look at some examples:

\- So in this case, Didi's operation got suspended because "Didi had illegally collected users' personal data."

\- Alibaba got fined because of monopolistic practices.

\- Ant Group's IPO got slashed because the CCP wanted to regulate Ant Group like an actual bank.

To be honest, these sound pretty reasonable to me. Facebook was in trouble for collecting data without content too. Remember the whole Cambridge Analytica scandal? But now everyone is hot for FB stocks.

Microsoft has been fined millions by the EU for monopolistic practices as well. But everyone loves Microsoft stocks nonetheless. 

And as to Ant Group, they are a massive financial service company that can offer customers credit. How come they don't get to be regulated like a bank? My point is that these actions make sense and good regulations is beneficial for investors too in the long run.

$NET is on a fundamental basis is over valued. They expect rev to be $500M+ this year but they trade at $33B. It’s been on of my biggest picked winners.

2) grow more into their cyber security suite of tools beyond just basic stuff like their widely used DDOS prevention (a ton of websites use them for this) and firewall 
3) Content delivery network investment trend continues and profit margins aren’t competed away with bigger boys entering the game (ie GOOG, MSFT, AMZN)
4) website speeds overwhelmingly determine ranking on google and mobile searches

Cloudflare and Fastly are the two more popular services for websites and apps to use as they offer ease of use to speed up website access for users and support to prevent website downtime. Folks have frequently complimented on how easy cloudflare is to use.

Microsoft in the 1990s was the most valuable company in the world switching spots with GE, it is currently the only company that was in the top 10 list in 1990 and is currently still top 10 right now (at #2 spot behind apple). It was the #1 company by marketcap in 2019 and march 2020.

Moreover, It has never fallen out of the top 10 list for more than 20+ years even with failure of Ballmer, tech bubble crash, Nokia, etc. Now with the new ceo, I dont see it going out of the top 10 especially since it is so far ahead from #10 spot which is Alibaba at 600 billion market cap. (Microsoft is worth 2.1 trillion).

author: harrison_wintergreen
body:
ELI5: 

- Burry believes (as he wrote): "passive investing has removed price discovery from the equity markets". https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-09-04/michael-burry-explains-why-index-funds-are-like-subprime-cdos

- price discovery is the process of estimating a reasonable fair value for a stock. 

- because relatively few people are buying/selling stocks based on their fair value, prices for stocks are often being determined mainly by cash-flows. see Tesla or dogecoin for examples. Tesla sells under 1% all vehicles worldwide but is somehow worth *more than all the other carmakers combined* because lots of people were buying Tesla stock and not because of any financial status of Tesla. dogecoin started LITERALLY as a joke but somehow was more valuable than companies like Ford Motors only because a ton of cash flowed into Dogecoin. this is all sheer insanity by traditional stock valuation guidelines. asset bubbles are nothing new, but Burry believes it's being exacerbated by passive investing. 

- Burry believes this situation of prices being based on cash flows is similar to what happened in the housing bubble, when multi-zillion Collateralized Debt Obligations (CDOs) were being priced not by a reasonable estimate of their fair value but by cash-flows. 

- when flows reverse and lots of people want out of index funds, it will get ugly because so many stocks are linked/benchmarked to major stock indexes *including lower volume stocks*. consider VTI: the top holdings (Apple, Microsoft, Johnson & Johnson) might have a billion shares in total and hundreds of millions of dollars trading each day. but the smallest company stocks might have only a few million shares and a few million dollars trading each day. if too many people want to sell all at the same time, it will drive prices down sharply because these stocks are so often sold as a bundle/unit. as Burry puts it: "The theater keeps getting more crowded, but the exit door is the same as it always was"

>since the guy predicted 2007-2008 crash.

he also predicted the dot-com bubble.

author: zxc123zxc123
body:
Hi. I'm from the Intel side! I think AMD side shouldn't worry too much about INTC. It's a big old ship that's getting bombarded from all sides. The fact that it's a big ship means it's changes will take time. I'm giving Gelsinger a chance to right the ship, but it will take a long while to undo BSwan's bad moves, get the right people, develop the chips, and catch up to AMD. 

A plus side for everyone is that the semi-space is a growing area with electronification, digitization, and "5G-cloudification" of everything along with the increasing importance of AI & tech in business and government. Semis are so important in fact, that at this point US Gov should really be looking at INTC/NVD/TI more like they did Ford/GM 100 years ago: as a strategic industrial/military resource. 

Real threat to AMD isn't INTC. INTC was the big market share holder in the past and isn't likely gaining any ground any time soon. What AMD and all the trad chip manufacturers should fear is FAAAM & BAT. Apple has started designing it's own chips. They aren't going back to using outsourced chips. If history says anything it's that Apple will continue to cut others out as they continue to in-house their chips for their entire lineup while improving their chips just like how they kept improving their computers, just like how the iphone kept improving until NOK/MOT were beat, just like how a good chunk of the watch market is Apple watches, just like how Ipads have taken away from of the laptop space, just like how Apple TV keeps chipping away at cable, just like how the app store and Apple's eco system keeps growing, etcetcetc. There is nothing AMD/NVD/INTC can do to stop Apple. And Apple is just the first. MSFT also doing the same. Google, Facebook, and Amazon might follow suit. China's Tencent and Alibaba will likely copy what the US companies do as soon as Pooh Bear gets done man handling them.

author: YourInnate
body:
It's a matter of perspective and big picture stuff. If you bough a SPY leap the day before the market crashed last year from covid, and bought 100 shares the day before the crash in covid, the LEAP would be worth more today.

2-5% a month seems super low, but options are a grind. When in doubt, zoom out. 2-5% a month is 25-60% a year. Consider the indexes historically return 10%, doubling that on your bad years and quintupling it on your good years seems like a good trade.

Another note, this past year has been a historic bull run/recovery for most of the stock market. You can't compare throwing money into microsoft or google and watching it appreciate vs selling options on the same underlying. Likewise, if you had been selling RIOT/MARA puts the first 4 months of the year, you could've been making 10% a week. 

Everything in the market is perspective. If you think 2-5% a month is too slow/boring... You might consider roulette.
